summary: In Topic 2.5 we started to discuss the different forms of membrane transport that allow substances to enter and exit the cell. Topic 2.6 dives deeper into the various types of membrane transport.

vocab.definition: A type of passive transport in which molecules move across a cell membrane through transport proteins (channels or carriers) down their concentration gradient, without additional energy
Integral membrane proteins that form pores in the membrane, allowing specific molecules or ions to pass through by diffusion
Channel proteins that act as water channels, selectively facilitating the rapid transport of water across cell membranes to maintain water homeostasis and osmotic balance in cells and tissues
Integral membrane proteins that facilitate the transport of specific molecules, ions, or small particles across the cell membrane by undergoing conformational changes
A protein in the cell membrane that performs active transport, pumping three sodium (Na+) ions out of the cell for every two potassium (K+) ions that are pumped in
The voltage or electrical potential difference across a cell's plasma membrane, generated by the unequal distribution of ions (like sodium, potassium, and chloride) inside and outside the cell
The combined force driving ions across a cell membrane, resulting from both a chemical gradient (difference in concentration) and an electrical gradient (difference in electrical charge)
